newsitem.title: FRANCE: About 300,000 attend Paris Catholic youth festival.
newsitem.headline: About 300,000 attend Paris Catholic youth festival.

text.p: About 300,000 pilgrims attended a colourful mass at the Eiffel Tower on Tuesday at the start of a Roman Catholic youth festival during which Pope John Paul will preach strict morality to an often sceptical flock.

Cardinal Jean-Marie Lustiger, Archbishop of Paris, led an open-air mass with dozens of cardinals and bishops before a congregation of young people waving banners and flags on the grass of the Champ-de-Mars park under sweltering, hazy sunshine.

One man carried a makeshift cross on his back. African drummers and dancers alternated with organists playing hymns and choirs chanting. On the fringes, souvenir sellers peddled commemorative T-shirts, hats and pens.

The mass, guarded by 1,700 police, marked the start of the week-long 12th World Youth Days, due to be attended by hundreds of thousands of young people from more than 160 countries and culminating with a mass by the Pope on Sunday.
The pontiff will visit Paris for four days from Thursday as part of a drive to counter a slide in religious zeal among the young, especially in rich nations like France.
"Finally we are together," Lustiger told the crowd estimated by police at roughly 300,000 people.
Many pilgrims acknowledged that, while they had come to Paris partly to see the Pope and for the religious ceremonies, they were also in France as tourists.
And many expressed scepticism about the Pontiff's moral teachings such as opposition to birth control and pre-marital sex.
"I'm not married and I have a baby so we all fall short of the graces of God," said 18-year-old American Temika Sosa of Las Cruces, New Mexico.

The Pope "is out of touch but it's also his responsibility to guide us morally," she added. "We need to be united in Christ, I think that's what's going to get us through the 20th century. Because everything's going to pot."

Lustiger urged the young to struggle to find love in Christ and follow the idealistic example of Saint Therese Martin, a French nun devoted to Christ who died of tuberculosis 100 years ago aged 24. The mass was dedicated to her.
"Do not give up! Do not choose mediocrity! God wants the greatest happiness for you!," he said.
Half a million people are expected to attend the festival's closing ceremony, a vast open-air mass to be celebrated by the Pope at the Longchamp racetrack on the western outskirts of Paris on Sunday.
Four million people attended a mass given by the Pope at the last World Youth Days in Manila two years ago.
